db:abstract.db:para: The QSignalTransition class provides a transition based on a Qt signal.
This class was introduced in Qt 4.6.

db:listitem.db:para: QSignalTransition is part of State Machine Classes

db:section.db:title: Detailed Description
db:section.db:para: Typically you would use the overload of QState::addTransition() that takes a sender and signal as arguments, rather than creating QSignalTransition objects directly. QSignalTransition is part of The State Machine Framework.
You can subclass QSignalTransition and reimplement eventTest() to make a signal transition conditional; the event object passed to eventTest() will be a QStateMachine::SignalEvent object. Example:

db:section.db:title: senderObject : QObject*
db:section.db:para: This property holds the sender object that this signal transition is associated with

db:note.db:para: This is a private signal. It can be used in signal connections but cannot be emitted by the user.

db:section.db:title: signal : QByteArray
db:section.db:para: This property holds the signal that this signal transition is associated with

db:note.db:para: This is a private signal. It can be used in signal connections but cannot be emitted by the user.

db:section.db:title: QSignalTransition::QSignalTransition(QState *sourceState = Q_NULLPTR)
db:section.db:para: Constructs a new signal transition with the given sourceState.

db:section.db:title: QSignalTransition::QSignalTransition(const QObject *sender, const char *signal, QState *sourceState = Q_NULLPTR)
db:section.db:para: Constructs a new signal transition associated with the given signal of the given sender, and with the given sourceState.

db:section.db:title: [since 5.7] QSignalTransition::QSignalTransition(const QObject *sender, int signal, QState *sourceState = Q_NULLPTR)
db:section.db:para: This is an overloaded function.

Constructs a new signal transition associated with the given signal of the given sender object and with the given sourceState. This constructor is enabled if the compiler supports delegating constructors, as indicated by the presence of the macro Q_COMPILER_DELEGATING_CONSTRUCTORS.
This function was introduced in Qt 5.7.

db:section.db:title: [virtual noexcept] QSignalTransition::~QSignalTransition()
db:section.db:para: Destroys this signal transition.

db:section.db:title: [override virtual protected] bool QSignalTransition::event(QEvent *e)
db:section.db:para: Reimplements: QAbstractTransition::event(QEvent *e).

db:section.db:title: [override virtual protected] bool QSignalTransition::eventTest(QEvent *event)
db:section.db:para: Reimplements: QAbstractTransition::eventTest(QEvent *event).
The default implementation returns true if the event is a QStateMachine::SignalEvent object and the event's sender and signal index match this transition, and returns false otherwise.

db:section.db:title: [override virtual protected] void QSignalTransition::onTransition(QEvent *event)
db:section.db:para: Reimplements: QAbstractTransition::onTransition(QEvent *event).

db:section.db:title: QObject *QSignalTransition::senderObject() const
db:section.db:para: Returns the sender object associated with this signal transition.

db:section.db:title: [since 5.4] void QSignalTransition::senderObjectChanged()
db:section.db:para: This signal is emitted when the senderObject property is changed.

db:note.db:para: This is a private signal. It can be used in signal connections but cannot be emitted by the user.

db:section.db:para: This function was introduced in Qt 5.4.

db:section.db:title: void QSignalTransition::setSenderObject(const QObject *sender)
db:section.db:para: Sets the sender object associated with this signal transition.

db:section.db:title: void QSignalTransition::setSignal(const QByteArray &signal)
db:section.db:para: Sets the signal associated with this signal transition.

db:section.db:title: QByteArray QSignalTransition::signal() const
db:section.db:para: Returns the signal associated with this signal transition.

db:section.db:title: [since 5.4] void QSignalTransition::signalChanged()
db:section.db:para: This signal is emitted when the signal property is changed.

db:note.db:para: This is a private signal. It can be used in signal connections but cannot be emitted by the user.
